iati-activity.reporting-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
iati-activity.title: Support to the National Malaria Control Programme
iati-activity.description: Malaria is the principal cause of sickness and death in Angola. The disease accounts for 25 percent of recorded illness in all age groups. The annual number of deaths recorded due to malaria is approximately 11,000, of which 35 percent are children under the age of five. The program supported by this grant aims to reduce illness and death from malaria by at least 25 percent by improving access to and the effective use of malaria treatment for children under five, pregnant women and the general population most at risk of infection. More specifically, grant monies are being used to improve access to and use of artemisinin-based combination therapy; improve access to and use of intermittent preventive treatment for pregnant women; and increase access and effective use of insecticide-treated bed nets by families with children under the age of five and pregnant women..

contact-info.organization: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

iati-activity.participating-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

iati-activity.reporting-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
iati-activity.title: Support to the National Tuberculosis Control Program
iati-activity.description: TB is a major public health problem in Angola. Although the country established a national program for the control of TB in 1981, nearly three decades of civil war have displaced 35 percent of the population, destroyed 70 percent of the country’s health facilities, and left a substantial proportion of the population vulnerable to the disease. The program supported by this grant will extend Directly-Observed Treatment, short course (DOTS) services to 68 municipalities in 11 provinces which do not currently have them, ensuring that there is at least one DOTS facility in each municipality. After laying a strong foundation for DOTS, the program will work to prevent circumstances that challenge DOTS expansion, such resistance to TB drugs and HIV/TB co-infection. The expected impact of the program is an increase in both case detection and treatment success, with a subsequent reduction in TB transmission, illness and fatality....

contact-info.organization: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

iati-activity.participating-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

iati-activity.reporting-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
iati-activity.title: Reducing the Burden of HIV/AIDS in Angola
iati-activity.description: Angola's large number of internally displaced persons, together with increased contact with military personnel, low levels of education, a young population and destroyed social networks, have made it a fertile breeding ground for the spread of HIV. The principal goal of the program supported by this grant is to prevent HIV transmission and reduce the socio-economic impact of the HIV epidemic in Angola. The program aims to achieve its goals through the implementation an integrated approach targeted at multiple sectors that reinforces and extends existing efforts in HIV prevention, treatment and surveillance while increasing institutional capacity, mobilizing and supporting people living with HIV and AIDS, coordinating partners and monitoring the distribution and use of resources.

contact-info.organization: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

iati-activity.participating-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

iati-activity.reporting-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
iati-activity.title: Scaling Up Malaria Interventions in Angola
iati-activity.description: Malaria remains the major public health problem in Angola and is reported to be the principal cause of sickness and death in the country. As a result of conflict, Angola's malaria control activities were significantly constrained for many years. The program supported by this grant builds on activities undertaken in the first phase of a program that received Global Fund financing in Round 3 and aims to achieve a 60 percent reduction of the impact of malaria in Angola by 2012. Targeting the two most vulnerable groups to malaria – children under five years of age and pregnant women – the program will use grant monies to procure and distribute long-lasting insecticide-treated bed nets free of charge to families in need; increase access to artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) treatment; and disseminate information on malaria prevention and treatment.

contact-info.organization: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

iati-activity.participating-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

iati-activity.reporting-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
iati-activity.title: Expanding and improving Diagnostic and Treatment Services for Tuberculosis in Angola
iati-activity.description: Tuberculosis (TB) remains a major public health problem in Angola. According to World Health Organization’s (WHO) Global TB Control Report 2009, the number of new sputum smear positive cases notified increased almost threefold, from approximately 7,379 to more than 21,422 between 1999 and 2007. WHO estimates that there are 48,777 new TB cases and between 2002 and 2007, Directly Observed Treatment Short-course (DOTS) coverage increased from 43 to 63 percent. The National Strategic Plan from 2008 to 2012 aims at extending DOTS network to the entire country and expanding the coverage of laboratories and caring for TB/HIV patients. The program will target vulnerable population in urban and rural communities in 18 provinces of Angola and HIV positive patients. The activities of the program will include creating new service points for DOTS, providing equipment and material to existing laboratories, producing and disseminating information education, and communication materials to TB and TB/HIV patients, providing quality supervision to laboratories, provincial and municipal facilities, and training staff involved in program implementation at the national, provincial, municipal and health facilities level.

contact-info.organization: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

iati-activity.participating-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

transaction.disbursement-channel: Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
